issues.title: Gap Analysis: Modelling of Optical Pluggables in Packet Over Optical Network
issues.author: dieterbeller
issues.body:
This gap analysis is trying to collect YANG models from various sources (primarily from IETF, OpenConfig, etc.) for modeling optical pluggables located in client devices like IP routers, which are connected to an optical WDM transport network. This material will be analyzed in order to identify potential gaps.

References:
- https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang
- https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/ietf-ccamp-layer0-types-ext-RFC9093-bis
- https://github.com/openconfig/public
- etc.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
I would propose to pull out the figures from the main body as in PR #4 

Then it is simpler to check whether each figure exceeds the 72 characters limit

It might be useful to check if there are some tools or scripts that can check and identify which lines are exceeding the 72 characters limit

issues.title: Review of I-D 00 version
issues.author: sergiobelotti
issues.body: This issues has to collect possible comments/suggestions on the first version (00) of I-D proposed .

comments.author: sergiobelotti
comments.body:
Some comments:
-_Normative reference_
Add Optical Impairments draft “A YANG Data Model for Optical Impairment-aware Topology”  [draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang-14 - A YANG Data Model for Optical Impairment-aware Topology](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang/14/)
Add Interface model draft “A YANG model to manage the optical interface parameters for an external transponder in a WDM network” [draft-ietf-ccamp-dwdm-if-param-yang-10 - A YANG model to manage the optical interface parameters for an external transponder in a WDM network](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-ccamp-dwdm-if-param-yang/)
-_Abstract_
I would change the sentence” Drawing from existing models in IETF, OpenConfig, ITU-T, OIF, and TAPI, this model offers enhanced uniform structuring and naming.” Into
“Drawing from existing IETF models, maybe be complementing that with input from other standard or industrial forum models (ITU-T, OpenConfig , ONF TAPI  etc.) , this model offers enhanced uniform structuring and naming.”
About the attributes as said we start with IETF attributes from Optical Impairment and then we need to understand if those are enough or not, and then we can dig into other models to see if e.g. OpenConfig is proposing something needed for us.

 “Additionally, it provides insight into the mapping to plug interface structures defined in CMIS.” 

About CMIS and the need to expose internal protocol between host and pluggable I’m personally not clear the need for that. 
Considering the CMIS interface as a device-internal interface  I think that a very limited amount of information needs to be exposed to the controller defined in a YANG module. 
The purpose of the YANG model should be to ensure that the transceiver optical pluggable is configured
properly from an optical WDM network perspective (TX/RX frequency setting/power setting/operational mode setting, etc).

_-Introduction_
I think we need to clarify and then converge, on what is the real purpose of this model. As I said in my view what we need to model is the necessary configuration parameters that are important from an optical transport network perspective. This seems map on the first bullet you have in the introduction:
“Optical media interface: This defines the characteristics of the optical solution such as spectrum, polarization, and dispersion, which do not directly affect the behavior of the host packet device.”
So this bullet means that our model should provide the correct parameters needed for an optical PNC to calculate suitable optical circuit and spectrum allocation.

I do not understand how the second and third bullet that you mention is affecting the needed attributes to be configured in the prospective of an optical feasibility computation. 
The second bullet seems to me more an internal set of characteristics that should be clarified why would be need to expose.
The third bullet seems related to specific physical characteristics of the pluggable , we would need to go into details here to understand if needed to be exposed in the model.

comments.author: dieterbeller
comments.body:
General comments:

- It looks like comments cannot be easily added to the I-D [draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md](https://github.com/italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/blob/main/draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md) in markdown format (maybe I just don't know how to do it).
- I created the txt file based on [draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md](https://github.com/italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/blob/main/draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md) and pasted it into this comment below.
- The txt file should always be put on GitHub next to the markdown file and should be kept in sync with the markdown file.

```
Common Control and Measurement Plane                            R. Rokui
Internet-Draft                                                     Ciena
Intended status: Informational                                    A. Guo
Expires: 27 August 2024                           Futurewei Technologies
                                                               P. Bedard
                                                                   Cisco
                                                          B. Swamynathan
                                                                   Nokia
                                                              G. Grammel
                                                                 Juniper
                                                        24 February 2024


     Modelling of Optical Pluggables in Packet Over Optical Network
         draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling-latest

Abstract

   This draft outlines the modeling of optical pluggables within a host
   packet device within the context of a packet over optical network.
   The model encompasses all pertinent properties of the pluggable for
   various packet over optical use cases and is partitioned into three
   primary areas: the optical media interface, the electrical plug to
   host interconnect, and the physical equipment of the pluggable.

   Included in the model are representations of configuration, states,
   and telemetry data, as well as profiles and coherent plug
   capabilities.  Emphasizing the importance of considering both vendor-
   agnostic and vendor-specific attributes in modeling coherent
   pluggables.

   Drawing from existing models in IETF, OpenConfig, ITU-T, OIF, and
   TAPI, this model offers enhanced uniform structuring and naming.
   Additionally, it provides insight into the mapping to plug interface
   structures defined in CMIS.

About This Document

   This note is to be removed before publishing as an RFC.

   The latest revision of this draft can be found at
   https://italobusi.github.io/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/draft-poidt-
   ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.html.  Status information for this
   document may be found at https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-
   poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/.






Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 1]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   Discussion of this document takes place on the Common Control and
   Measurement Plane Working Group mailing list (mailto:ccamp@ietf.org),
   which is archived at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/ccamp/.
   Subscribe at https://www.ietf.org/mailman/listinfo/ccamp/.

   Source for this draft and an issue tracker can be found at
   https://github.com/italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.

Status of This Memo

   This Internet-Draft is submitted in full conformance with the
   provisions of BCP 78 and BCP 79.

   Internet-Drafts are working documents of the Internet Engineering
   Task Force (IETF).  Note that other groups may also distribute
   working documents as Internet-Drafts.  The list of current Internet-
   Drafts is at https://datatracker.ietf.org/drafts/current/.

   Internet-Drafts are draft documents valid for a maximum of six months
   and may be updated, replaced, or obsoleted by other documents at any
   time.  It is inappropriate to use Internet-Drafts as reference
   material or to cite them other than as "work in progress."

   This Internet-Draft will expire on 27 August 2024.

Copyright Notice

   Copyright (c) 2024 IETF Trust and the persons identified as the
   document authors.  All rights reserved.

   This document is subject to BCP 78 and the IETF Trust's Legal
   Provisions Relating to IETF Documents (https://trustee.ietf.org/
   license-info) in effect on the date of publication of this document.
   Please review these documents carefully, as they describe your rights
   and restrictions with respect to this document.  Code Components
   extracted from this document must include Revised BSD License text as
   described in Section 4.e of the Trust Legal Provisions and are
   provided without warranty as described in the Revised BSD License.

Table of Contents

   1.  Terminology . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   3
   2.  Introduction  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   3
   3.  Packet over optical converged network context . . . . . . . .   5
   4.  Optical Pluggable Building Blocks . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   6
   5.  Optical Pluggables Data Modeling  . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
   6.  Optical Pluggables Yang Model . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
   7.  Security Considerations . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7



Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 2]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   8.  IANA Considerations . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
   9.  References  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
     9.1.  Normative References  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
     9.2.  Informative References  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8
   Acknowledgments . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8
   Contributors  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8
   Authors' Addresses  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8

1.  Terminology

   The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
   "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and
   "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in
   BCP 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all
   capitals, as shown here.

   The following terms abbreviations are used in this document:

   *  Optical Plug / Coherent Pluggables / Pluggable: A small form
      factor coherent optical module

   *  O-PNC: The control functions specializing in management/control of
      optical and photonic functions (virtual or physical).  See
      [RFC8453]

   *  P-PNC: The control functions specializing in management/control of
      packet functions (virtual or physical).  See [RFC8453]

   *  CMIS: Content Management Interoperability Services developed by
      OIF is an open standard that allows different content management
      systems to inter-operate over the Internet

   *  xPonder: Short for Transponder and/or Muxponder

2.  Introduction

   Packet traffic has been transmitted across optical networks for many
   years, leveraging the advantages of optical transmission and
   switching combined with packet switching.  Traditionally, optical
   systems and packet systems have been distinct, each with their own
   dedicated devices.

   In numerous network setups, packet and optical networks have been
   engineered, operated, and managed separately, leading to siloed
   operations that can be suboptimal and inefficient.  The evolution of
   both packet and optical systems has largely been independent.
   Optical systems, in particular, have seen advancements in capacity,
   especially with the adoption of coherent optical techniques.



Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 3]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   Advancements in optical component design have led to increased
   density, enabling entire coherent optical terminal systems that
   previously required multiple circuit packs to now fit into a single
   small form factor "coherent pluggable."  Integrating coherent
   pluggables into devices with packet functions can result in reduced
   network costs, power consumption, and footprint, while also enhancing
   data transfer rates, reducing latency, and expanding capacity,
   although in some cases, separate packet and optical solutions may
   still be preferred due to other engineering and deployment
   considerations.

   These trends, coupled with the desire to utilize the best components
   available, have given rise to open optical pluggables.  These
   pluggables allow a plug from one vendor to be installed in a device
   from another vendor with packet functions.  Communication between
   coherent pluggables and the packet device host occurs through the
   CMIS standard developed by OIF [OIF-CMIS].

   While standardized transmission modes like ZR can handle basic
   applications, proprietary modes from vendors are often necessary to
   achieve optimal performance.

   This draft outlines the modeling of an optical pluggable within a
   host packet device within the context of a packet over optical
   network.  The model presented in this document consolidates various
   properties of optical pluggables into three key areas:

   *  Optical media interface: This defines the characteristics of the
      optical solution such as spectrum, polarization, and dispersion,
      which do not directly affect the behavior of the host packet
      device.

   *  Electrical plug-to-host interconnect: This defines the
      characteristics of the bus interconnect between the host and the
      plug, such as lane count and FEC, which both the optical pluggable
      and the packet host must understand and act upon.

   *  Physical and functional aspects of the pluggable: This defines
      attributes of the optical pluggable itself, such as plug type,
      version, thermal characteristics, and power consumption, which
      indirectly affect the packet host.










Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 4]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   The coherent pluggable model provides representations for
   capabilities, profiles, configurations, and states and telemetry
   data.  Capabilities are defined in profiles related to operational
   modes, with some capabilities potentially being proprietary
   Configurations include attributes for optical settings, monitoring
   capabilities, and test capabilities, while state and telemetry data
   include dynamic properties such as performance monitoring collections
   and alarm notifications.

   Both vendor-agnostic and vendor-specific attributes are important
   considerations in the modeling of coherent pluggables.

   The document is divided into the following sections:

   *  Section 3: Packet over optical converged network context

   *  Section 4: Coherent Pluggables Building Blocks

   *  Section 5: Coherent Pluggables Data Modeling

   *  Section 6: Coherent Pluggables Yang Model

3.  Packet over optical converged network context




























Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 5]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


                  |---------------|
                  |   P-PNC(s),   |
                  |   O-PNC(s),   |
                  |   MDSC        |
                  |---------------|
                          ^
                          |  (A)
      +-------------------|-------------------+
      |                   |                   |  Packet Device
      |                   V                   |  Vendor X
      |        |---------------------|        |  (i.e, Host)
      |        |                     |        |
      |        v                     v        |
      |  |-----------|          |----------|  |
      |  | Packet    |          | Coherent |  |
      |  | Function  |..........| Plug     |  |
      |  | Data      |          | Data     |  |
      |  |-----------|          |----------|  |
      |        .                      .       |
      |        .                      . (B)   |
      |        .                      .       |
      |  |--------------|   (C)   |------------------|  (D)
      |  |Packet Device |<------->| Coherent Plug #1 |=======
      |  |Function      |<---|    | Vendor X         |
      |  |--------------|    |    |------------------|
      |                      |                |
      |                      |    |------------------|
      |                      |--->| Coherent Plug #2 |=======
      |                           | Vendor Y         |
      |                           |------------------|
      |                                       |
      +---------------------------------------+

  Legend
    (A) Packet device management interfaces (e.g., YANG, NETCONF, gNMI, etc.)
    (B) CMIS interface between Optical pluggable and Host
    (C) Host side of the optical pluggable (towards the Host)
    (D) Media side of the optical pluggable (towards Optical/Photonic network)

           Figure 1: Packet device with optical pluggables

4.  Optical Pluggable Building Blocks









Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 6]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


     Optical Pluggable
     |--------------------------------------------------------------------------|
     |                                                                          |
     |                Host side                         Media side              |
     | |---------------------------------|  |---------------------------------| |
     | |                                 |  |                                 | |
     | | |-----------|    |-----------|  |  | |-----------|    |-----------|  | |
  -------| Electrical|    | Host      |  |  | | Media     |    | Optical   | -----> (Tx)
  -------| Channel   |----| Logical   |-------| Logical   |....| Channel   | <----- (Rx)
  -------|           |    | Channels  |  |  | | Channels  |    | (OTSI)    |  | |
     | | |-----------|    |-----------|  |  | |-----------|    |-----------|  | |
     | |                                 |  |                                 | |
     | |---------------------------------|  |---------------------------------| |
     |                                                                          |
     | |----------------------------------------------------------------------| |
     | |                            Equipment/inventory                       | |
     | |----------------------------------------------------------------------| |
     |                                                                          |
     |--------------------------------------------------------------------------|

             Figure 2: Optical Pluggable Building Blocks

5.  Optical Pluggables Data Modeling

6.  Optical Pluggables Yang Model

7.  Security Considerations

   TODO Security

8.  IANA Considerations

   This document has no IANA actions.

9.  References

9.1.  Normative References

   [OIF-CMIS] OIF Forum, "OIF Implementation Agreement (IA) Common
              Management Interface Specification (CMIS))", OIF CMIS IA ,
              April 2022, <https://www.oiforum.com/wp-content/uploads/
              OIF-CMIS-05.2.pdf>.

   [RFC2119]  Bradner, S., "Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate
              Requirement Levels", BCP 14, RFC 2119,
              DOI 10.17487/RFC2119, March 1997,
              <https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2119>.




Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 7]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   [RFC8174]  Leiba, B., "Ambiguity of Uppercase vs Lowercase in RFC
              2119 Key Words", BCP 14, RFC 8174, DOI 10.17487/RFC8174,
              May 2017, <https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8174>.

9.2.  Informative References

   [RFC8453]  Ceccarelli, D., Ed. and Y. Lee, Ed., "Framework for
              Abstraction and Control of TE Networks (ACTN)", RFC 8453,
              DOI 10.17487/RFC8453, August 2018,
              <https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8453>.

Acknowledgments

   TODO acknowledge.

Contributors

   Nigel Davis
   Ciena
   Email: ndavis@ciena.com


   Italo Busi
   Huawei Technologies
   Email: italo.busi@huawei.com


   Sergio Belotti
   Nokia
   Email: sergio.belotti@nokia.com


   Dieter Beller
   Nokia
   Email: dieter.beller@nokia.com


   Roberto Manzotti
   Cisco

Authors' Addresses

   Reza Rokui
   Ciena
   Email: rrokui@ciena.com




Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 8]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   Aihua Guo
   Futurewei Technologies
   Email: aihuaguo.ietf@gmail.com


   Phil Bedard
   Cisco
   Email: phbedard@cisco.com


   B Swamynathan
   Nokia
   Email: swamynathan.b@nokia.com


   Gert Grammel
   Juniper

Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 9]
```

comments.author: dieterbeller
comments.body:
Afaik, an OIF Implementation Agreement (IA) cannot be a normative reference in an IETF RFC:

```
9.1.  Normative References

   [OIF-CMIS] OIF Forum, "OIF Implementation Agreement (IA) Common
              Management Interface Specification (CMIS))", OIF CMIS IA ,
              April 2022, <https://www.oiforum.com/wp-content/uploads/
              OIF-CMIS-05.2.pdf>.
```
It can only be an informative reference!

I concur with the comment from @sergiobelotti above that the CMIS interface is a device-internal interface and the configuration parameters for pluggables, which shall be exposed to controllers via a potential YANG model (those relevant for the optical WDM transport network), must be selected carefully. This is at least my understanding of the scope of this draft.

issues.title: Correcting Figure 3
issues.author: ggrammel
issues.body: The figure 3 does not work like indicated. Some host controller needs to separate the traffic between controllers (switch/router/...). needs alignment with the figure in the Google spreadsheet "Scope" top-right. also the naming of the interfaces should align. Furthermore, the PNC(s) are identified as a single box while it appears they are identified as different entities. Suggest to align the figure with the figure in the excel table comparison.

      |        |                     |        |

issues.title: Point to Multi point pluggable (P2MP) attributes
issues.author: vharish02
issues.body: Should we add P2MP attributes to this draft if there any additional attributes that are part of P2MP like identify sub-carriers and mapping of sub-carriers to client.

comments.body:
Hi All,

I can’t attend the call today dua to a conflict.

Sorry about that,

Best Regards,

Gabriele Galimberti

Via Melgacciata, 13
20813 – Bovisio Masciago (MB)
Italy

+39 3357481947

Cc: Gabriele Galimberti ***@***.***>, Review requested ***@***.***>
Oggetto: Re: [italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling] Add/modify the v00 of draft. (PR #9)


@reza-github commented on this pull request.

________________________________

In draft-rokui-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md<https://github.com/italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/pull/9#discussion_r1808596674>:

>

 4. The data flow between the coherent pluggable and the packet data function through this interface. This is electrical interface between coherent pluggable and the host. {{building-blocks}} will discuss this in more details.



 5. Optical fiber connecting the optical devices to optical pluggables. This carries the flow of photonic signal from the optical device to the coherent pluggables. {{building-blocks}} will discuss this in more details.



-This draft presents the modeling of the coherent pluggable such as #1 and #2 in {{figure-details-packet-optical-device}} within a host packet device. The model presented in {{data-model}} consolidates properties of coherent pluggable on interfaces (4) and (5) where interface (5) provides the photonic/optical attributes and interface provides the host/electrical attributes.

+This draft presents the modeling of the coherent pluggable such as (4) and (5) in {{figure-details-packet-optical-device}} within a host packet device. The model presented in {{data-model}} consolidates properties of coherent pluggable on interfaces (4) and (5) where interface (5) provides the photonic/optical attributes and interface provides the host/electrical attributes.

I have replaced the original text with your suggested one.

—

reviews.author: philbedard
reviews.body: I saw a couple of minor typos in the document which I made comments on, otherwise it looks good.

comments.body: Done
Done
Done
I'm still not convinced that we should deal with electrical part , but we can debate.

This part "The lifecycle of a coherent pluggable including operators' approval, viability assessment to deployment and deployment is also covered." is not  a repetition  of what already present above?

Just to better understand what is supposed to be defined here: the sentence is supposing can be possible to separate the host packet control from optical pluggable,correct? 
If yes it seems to be possible to suppose two different controller can act on the two different block of function . Is that what you're supposing?

It is missing the number of interface: "....... where interface (5) provides the photonic/optical attributes and interface ??provides the host/electrical attributes."
Need to add interface (4)

I would reword a bit : " Note that the purpose of this section is to clarify  the role of electrical channel in the coherent pluggable" 
and "The purpose of this draft is not ...."

I do not like the term "method" to define the different type of "mode" to describe pluggable capabilities. We can define "approaches to describe the pluggable capabilities" as in Optical Impairment draft (section 2.6) . 
I would reword the last sentence in this way: "A coherent pluggable can support multiple supported modes, each of which can be defined by one of the following 3 categories  as defined in Optical Impairment (draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang) in section 2.6:
-STANDARD mode (see 2.6.1 of draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang)
-Organizational mode (see 2.6.2 of ....)
-Explicit mode (see 2.6.3 of ...)

Shall we really re-define again what already defined in OI ? My preference would be to reference what already defined instead to use different wording to define things already present since long time in another draft.
Same comment. To describe coherent pluggable capabilities we have defined three different approaches called "modes" , and should reference them.

Again: the text is a bit confused and trying to re-define what already defined in OI. If we want to add text related to coherent pluggable capabilities way to describe them,, let's take a summary of what defined in section 2.6 of OI draft. Using other words and terminology is creating misunderstanding .
What is the purpose of this piece of text?

We already defined in OI YANG organization-mode that is identified by organization identifier + operational-mode. 
You use the same name attributes in a different way creating confusion to whom is familiar with RFC9093-bis and OI YANG model.
not clear the intent to me.
nothing is changed and the repetition is still present.
Nothing changed , you need to add interface 4 !!!!
for me the wording is still not clear. Please follow my suggestion above.

sure we can discuss this. 
IMO, Electrical side is not needed for configuration but is needed for telemetry PM and alarms (for troubleshooting)
You are right. It is removed.

Yes it is possible.
This can be one deployment model (aka Realization) operator might use. There might be other deployments. The point of this sentence is just separation of responsibilities for IP and Optical
Nice catch. Added
Agreed. Replaced
Sergio, since this needs for discussion, my suggestion is to keep this comment open and have  more discussions during our weekly meetings.

This is the intent. 
So, would you suggest what is needed to be added/replaced here?
Similar to previous comment, let's have this item as one of the topics for discussion during our weekly meetings.
Similar to previous comment, let's have this item as one of the topics for discussion during our weekly meetings.

the intention is this:
Regardless of which authority defined this mode, the list of "Capability Attributes" represented by this mode are important.
Similar to previous comment, let's have this item as one of the topics for discussion during our weekly meetings.

Are you referring to "tag"?
If so, the intention is to have something similar to service-tag introduced in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-teas-ietf-network-slice-nbi-yang-07
Its purpose is to provide flexibility to the pluggable YANG for future extensibility. As described, one example might be mapping of supported-mode to CMIS media-ID.
Can you suggest what is needed to be replaced/removed? I will revise the text
Can you suggest what is needed to be replaced/removed? I will revise the text
Can you suggest an alternative text. I will add it

It seems to me that this part "This document also covers an analysis of the gap between current IETF drafts and the corresponding works in other standards bodies and industry. The lifecycle of a coherent pluggable including operators' approval, viability assessment to deployment and deployment is also covered." is already reported before and it seems a repetition with other words. Am I missed something?

"The model presented in {{data-model}} consolidates properties of coherent pluggable on interfaces (4) and (5) where interface (5) provides the photonic/optical attributes and interface provides the host/electrical attributes."
You need to add "....and interface (4) provides the host/electrical attributes"

I would reword a bit : " Note that the purpose of this section is to clarify the role of electrical channel in the coherent pluggable"
and "The purpose of this draft is not ...."
Done

this sentence outlines two aspects:
1- this talk about life cycle of coherent Pluggables
2- Covering Gap analysis
Both are not discussed in previous sentences.
I have replaced the original text with your suggested one.

pulls.title: Update draft-rokui-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md
pulls.author: ggrammel
pulls.body: Correcting Figure 3 #6 in line with Presentation made at IETF 120: https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/120/materials/slides-120-ccamp-use-cases-network-scenarios-and-gap-analysis-for-packet-optical-integration-poi-with-coherent-plugables-under-actn-framework-00

comments.author: reza-github
comments.body: Agreed. Your suggestion is included in the latest version.
